Data Formats and Databases

Data Formats

Weâ€™ll be mainly discussing data available in â€œhuman-readableâ€ formatsâ€¦ ğŸ‘€

Ummmâ€¦ what do we mean by saying that? â†’

  • the physical file is formattedâ€¦
  • and the data is stored in such a way ğŸ’¾
  • that one can open it in a text editor (notepad, textedit), and actually read it ğŸ“
  • sometimes, files that store human-readable data are called plain-text files

Data Formats - Examples

Can you think of examples of some human readable file formats and their file name extensions? â†’

  • TXT (generally tab-delimited or fixed width)
  • CSV (comma-separated values; comma-delimited)
  • XML (Extensible Mark-up Language)
  • JSON (JavaScript Object Notation)

Are there any other data formats that youâ€™ve encountered? â†’

Letâ€™s go through these formats in more detail! â†’

.TXT and .CSV Files

Tab-delimited and Comma Separated Values files (.txt and .csv respectively) are widely available online and from a variety of data sources.

These files are â€œhuman-readableâ€ and can be easily imported into spreadsheets and databases. â€¦ Some examples:

  • Tab-delimited: U.S. Census School districts
  • Comma-separated values or comma-delimited: NYC Open data list of colleges

Letâ€™s check out some of these files in a text editor, as well as a spreadsheetâ€¦ â†’

.TXT and .CSV Files Continued

What are some observations that you can make about these files? â†’

  • may or may not have a first row of column headers
  • headers may be difficult to interpret without companion documentation or data dictionary
    • hereâ€™s a crazy example of some very thorough documentation for this set of data for the USDA National Nutrient Database
  • CSV can mean delimited by a character other than comma! (ğŸ˜²)
  • what if you want the separator character in your actual data? (one strategy: â€œwrap it in quotation marksâ€)

.TXT and .CSV Summary

  • human readable, plain text format
  • language and platform independent
  • represents tabular data: columns represents fields, row represents entity (thing being stored)
  • first row may be header (defines columns / fields)
  • values in rows are separated by a specific character
    • common delimiters (separator character) include:
    • commas, tabs and pipes
field1, field2, field3
foo, bar, baz
qux, quux, corge

Markup Languages

Before we talk about XML, letâ€™s discuss markup languages:

  • system of annotating content (text, images, etc.) âœï¸
  • the syntax of the annotations make the annotations easily distinguishable from the actual content itself
  • some examples:
    • text processing commands in LaTeX â€¦
    • tags in both HTML (â€œview source on this page!) and XML

Tags

Note that HTML and XML use tags for annotation ğŸ·ï¸

  • a tag is an annotation where the annotation itself appears between less than (<) and greater than signs (>)
  • and the content often appears between a set of two tags (an opening and closing tag)
<tagName>Some great content goes here!</tagName>

.XML

Speaking of XML and tagsâ€¦

  • eXtensible Markup Language
  • looks a lot like another markup language: html <ğŸ˜ºğŸ˜º>
  • known for being verboseâ€¦ ğŸ—£ï¸
  • particularly suited for modeling data that:
    • has a nested structure â€¦
    • like a parent/child ğŸ‘©â€ğŸ‘¦â€ğŸ‘¦ or a tree-like relationship among data ğŸŒ³

XML Continued

XML itself is the building block of other languages / file formats

  • itâ€™s a general markup language in that it defines syntax, but not tags; you must define tags yourself through an XML Schema (or alternatively, through a Document Type Declaration)
  • an XML Schema imposes user defined constraints on the structure and content of an XML file ğŸ”¨
    • essentially, the schema defines the semantic rules that an XML file must conform to!
  • â€¦which means other markup languages (and consequently other file formats) are built on top of XML ğŸ—ï¸

Formats Built on XML

Can you think of any file formats that are built on top of XML â†’

  • SVG - Scalable Vector Graphics
    • letâ€™s draw a rectangle or check out an example of some basic shapes) â†’
  • TEI - Text Encoding Initiative - markup that provides structural and descriptive meta data, like sentences, words and lines about text
    • see the examples on wikipedia or take a look at a poem by William Carlow Williams) â†’
  • and sooooo many othersâ€¦ including Resource Description Framework, Really Simple Syndication, XHTML, and MathML

Displaying XML

Typically, viewing XML in a text editor (or even your browser) results in all of the text (including the tags) being displayed â€¦

  • one way to format and style the display of an XML file is to use eXtensible Stylesheet Language
  • XSL is a family (XSL Transformation, XML Path Language, etc.) of powerful languages that transform and render styled and formatted XML
  • (or even transform XML into different formats, such as regular HTML)

XML Summary

  • human readable, plain text format
  • language and platform independent
  • self-describing (through a schema and tags) and great for nested or tree like data
  • tags annotate text and provide structure, semantics and meta data to content
  • see pottery example XML file â†’

JSON

JSON: JavaScriptÂ ObjectÂ Notation

  • a text-based data interchange format
  • it is language and platform independent; and, like XML, is also considered â€œself-describingâ€.
  • JSON is known for its key-value pairs where keys are similar to names/labels/properties, and values can be numbers, text, â€œobjectsâ€ or lists of values
  • for those with Python experience, this looks like a dictionary! (letâ€™s see some examplesâ€¦ â†’)

JSON Examples

Unlike XML, JSON does not require a predefined schema. With that said, youâ€™ll find the JSON is still used as a common building block for other formats

  • â€¦for example: GeoJSON for geo-spatial data, such as longitude and latitude coordinates
  • other examples include
    • a complete set of U.S. zip codes in JSON from mongodb.org
    • stats.nba.com loads data from json files (check out Chromeâ€™s developer tools)
    • JSON is a very common data interchange format for the web

Unstructured Data

  • the previous data we saw was structured: it was organized in a predefined way
  • scholars who use literature for textual analysis will often refer to their sources as unstructured data.
  • for example, Tolstoyâ€™s War and Peace might be considered unstructured data consisting of words ğŸ“š
  • what are some other unstructured datasets that you can think of? â†’ (hint: see the wikipedia)
    • journals, health records, songs / popular music, film / tv, images,
    • portions of structured data may be unstructured: body of an email, parts of a web page, or parts of a word-processor doc, a tweet, blog entry ğŸ™ƒ

Spreadsheets vs Databases

What are factors should be considered when deciding which to use? ğŸ¤” â†’

  • volume of data / number of records
    • for example, the list of school districts from the US Census might be too cumbersome to handle with a spreadsheet
    • very large data sets on the order of gigabytes or terabytesâ€¦ even though office can handle them; itâ€™s limited by available main memory)

Spreadsheets vs Databases Continued

  • level of precision for calculations
    • with spreadsheets, youâ€™re stuck with the limitations that your spreadsheet application gives you
    • for example Excel may be accurate up to 15 significant figures
  • the nature of your dataâ€¦ textual, numeric, images, etc.?
    • spreadsheets arenâ€™t traditionally used to store non-numeric and non-textual data (images, video, audio, etc.)

Spreadsheets vs Databases Continued More

  • programmatic / automated manipulation of data
    • while spreadsheets provide programming facilities, they are usually not as robust as dedicated programming languages / environments
    • pre-built libraries and modules for programming are usually geared towards databases rather than spreadsheets

Databases FTW?

Hmmm. It looks like databases win. All. The. Time. â€¦

  • BUTâ€¦ thereâ€™s rather a lot of overhead for:
    • learning how to use a database and setting one up
  • more often than not, a spreadsheet will suffice for quick data analysis and data visualization ğŸ’¨ğŸ“ˆ
  • (and perhaps even for backing small, read-only. database driven sites)
  • spreadsheets are also a great tool for prototyping or testing out ideas

what are the data sets that youâ€™re working with? whatâ€™s the volume of data? any issues so far? â†’

SO MANY DATABASES

We can categorize databases as: â†’

  • relational
  • nosql (also non-relational)


nosql databases can be further categorized by the data model they use: â†’

  • key-value
  • document
  • column
  • graph

Warning: Broad Generalizations Coming Up!

So, the following slides include high level overviews of different kinds of databases.

  • Iâ€™m going to use broad generalizations âš ï¸
  • but there are always exceptions

Relational Databases

Relational databases organize data in a collection of tables (relations). â†’

  • each table has named columnsâ€¦ with the actual data that populates the table in separate rows
  • each table row has primary key that:
    • uniquely identifies that row
    • allows data in one table to be related to data in another (via foreign key relationships)

Relational Databases Continued

Regarding additional relational database featuresâ€¦ â†’

  • relational databases are typically pretty rigid:
    • highly structured
    • columns and the types of columns must be defined before inserting rows
    • has features for maintaining data integrity (user defined data constraints, foreign keys, etc.)
  • some relational databases guarantee that transactions (or changes in the database) are reliable (what does that mean?) â€¦

Aside on ACID

Reliability and ACID compliance - Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, Durability

  • Atomicity - each transaction / (series of operations in a transaction) is all or nothing
  • Consistency - every transaction ensures that the resulting database state is valid (goes from one valid state to another)
  • Isolation - a failed transaction should have no effect on other transactions (even if the transactions are concurrent)
  • Durability - once a transaction / operation is done, the results will remain persistent even through crash, power loss, etc.

Quick Demo: Database Design

Letâ€™s use an ER Diagram to design tables and their relationships for storing the following data: â†’

  • first name
  • last name
  • street address
  • city
  • state
  • zip

Examples of Relational Databases

Relational databases can be organized based on where they are deployed / run from (though there is some overlap) â†’

  • Desktop
    • FileMaker Pro, OpenOffice/LibreOffice Base, Microsoft Access
  • Server
    • MySQL, PostgreSQL, Oracle, Microsoft SQL Server, SQL Lite

Letâ€™s examine the highlighted ones in more detail. â†’

FileMaker Pro

FileMaker Pro is a database server and graphical user interface

  • long history and successful product in many environments (cross-platform MacOS and Windows)
  • early desktop database to integrate multimedia, images, etc.; available for iPhone / iPad applications and one of the first to integrate with clientsâ€™ websites
  • anecdotally - seen used in small businesses / organizations / non-profitsâ€¦ for inventory management, donations, etc.
    • current stories
  • although not open source, widely used in the archival world (part of the Digital Humanities community)

Microsoft Access

  • great for teaching
  • MS-Access offers a UI (user-interface) as well as options for programming in Visual Basic and running SQL queries.
  • widely used in some industries for prototyping (building tables, sample data sets and a user interface for a product that would later run server-side.)
  • again, anecdotally, Iâ€™ve seen it used in small business for inventory management, client tracking, etc.

SQLite

  • SQLite is the most widely installed relational database as it is used with every Android and iPhone device.
  • open source and widely used; commonly embedded in desktop applications / used as a prototyping tool due to ease of deployment
    • see http://sqlite.org/famous.html
    • (e.g. Adobeâ€™s Photoshop LightRoom, Chrome to store cookie data)
  • can we used with many different programming languagesâ€¦ see SQLite Wrappers

MySQL

Live demoâ€¦ â†’

  • scripting in MySQL to create and populate tables, using gui
    • single table (books)
    • phpmyadmin for web interface
      • using the public trial version
  • writing queries in MySQL to analyze data
    • use er diagram to show relationships among tables
    • artists, paintings, media and countries â€“ MySQL demo
    • use commandline to browse

NoSQL Databases

NoSQL databases can be categorized by how they store their data:

  • key-value
  • document
  • column
  • graph
  • there are others
    • (such as object, tuple store, etc.)
    • check out a whole list
  • note that nosql databases can have reliable transactions as well, but this is usually not the focus of a nosql database


Weâ€™ll focus on document storesâ€¦

Document Stores

As you might guess by the name, document stores organize data semi-structured documents.

  • think JSON (but there are many possible formats, such as XML, YAML, etc.)
  • orâ€¦ a richer key-value store (thereâ€™s meta data within the documentâ€¦ the keys are usually meaningful)
  • typically, no schema is required (that is, data types of values are inferred from values)
  • typically, semi structured (documents, property names, etcâ€¦ do not have to be pre-defined)
  • some document stores are particularly featureful when it comes to high availability and scaling (through replication/redundancy and sharding/separating large databases into smaller ones)


Theyâ€™re particularly good for applications where flexible data storage or constantly changing data storage is required.

Document Store Examples

Two of the most popular NoSQL databases are:

  • MongoDB
  • CouchDB

There are a bunch of others

Some use cases for document stores include:

  • applications that require semi structured data / data that has does not have rigid requirements (perhaps a resume)
  • again, large volumes of data
  • fluid data or data whose structure is prone to change

MongoDB

Itâ€™s a nosql database, specifically, a document storeâ€¦

  • a single record in Mongo is a document
  • a document is a bunch of key value pairsâ€¦
  • heyâ€¦ that sounds likeâ€¦ â†’
  • documents are similar to JSON objects

Documents and Collections

A couple of terms to remember (yay, definitions)

  • key - a field name - analogous to a column in a relational database
  • value - a value ğŸ¤”
  • document - a single object or record in our database,
    • consists of key value pairs
    • similar to a single row in a relational database
  • collection - a group of documents
    • analogous to tables in relational databases
